description: From English dis- +â€Ž favour, from Middle French desfaveur.

nouns.description: disfavour (countable and uncountable, plural disfavours) (British spelling)

examples: His lateness for the appointment incurred her disfavour.

entries.meaning: A state of being out of favour.

verbs.description: disfavour (third-person singular simple present disfavours, present participle disfavouring, simple past and past participle disfavoured)

entries.meaning: (British spelling) To show lack of favour or antipathy towards.
examples: Her past performance meant that she was often disfavoured for important tasks.
